sourceDesc.bibl: "Safe, Sure Birth Control Means Seen in 10 Years", Tuscon Daily Citizen, Aug. 12, 1959

headNote.p: Sanger spoke at a dinner held at the Mountain View Presbyterian Church in Scottsboro, AZ along with Planned Parenthood of Tuscon members Rev. Samuel J. Lindamood, Jr., Lois Nelson, and Della Kincaid. For additional newspaper coverage of this speech, see The Church and Birth Control, Aug. 11, 1959.

docBody.head: Safe, Sure Birth Control Means Seen In 10 Years

p.q: Ten more years should bring safe, sure and cheap means of birth control, Mrs. Margaret Sanger, founder of the Planned Parenthood Movement, said last night at Mountain View Presbyterian Church.
Mrs. Sanger was referring to the development of a hormone type pill. She said it was proving effective in experiments, but was not ready for the general market.

docBody.p: "That is what we need for worldwide progress," she said.

In one of her rare public appearances here since coming to live in Tucson 15 years ago, Mrs. Sanger said at the meeting in the church patio, "This is my first invitation to your church and I appreciate it deeply."
Mrs. Sanger appeared on the platform and answered about a dozen questions put to her, but attempted no speech.

p.q: The speakers on Planned Parenthood in Tucson were the Rev. Samuel J. Lindamood Jr., associate pastor; Mrs. Lois Nelson, a board member of the local association, and Mrs. Delia Kincaid, executive secretary.

docBody.p: Mrs. Sanger said she was a nurse in New York City.

p.q: Mrs. Sanger appeared on the platform and answered a dozen questions put to her, but attempted no speech.
She was presented by the Rev. Mr. Lindamood, who said:
She is a person we can admire very greatly. She is a pioneer who has overcome persecution with great grace."
The chairman's question to Mrs. Sanger was what had started her in the planned parenthood career.
Mrs. Sanger said she was a nurse in New York City.

docBody.p: "I saw the difference (in living conditions) among parents who could space their children from those who could not," she said.
"I began a crusade and was surprised by the difficulties," she added. "I became aware of federal laws, and state laws and religious prejudice."

p.q: Still a world traveler for the International Planned Parenthood movement, Mrs. Sanger recently returned from a second visit this year to the Far East. She said Japan had cut its birth rate in half the past two years, but that Red China "had the word from Russia to take down the signs and quit making the materials (for birth control).
She said birth control movements were spreading in India and other nations of Asia.

Mrs. Sanger candidly admitted that Japan relied heavily on abortions in reducing its birth rate. However, the public health service in Japan, she said, was seeking to protect the health of women by spreading information about safer means of spacing children.

docBody.p: In the United States she said "the careless ones who know nothing are the ones having the children they can't care for."

p.q: Mrs. Nelson said the Tucson Planned Parenthood clinic had been in operation here for 25 years. Mrs. Kincaid said the clinic now at 55 E. Jackson St. is open from 10 a.m. to 4 p.m. daily. She said three clinic sessions are held weekly for women referred to it by doctors, ministers, or interested people and those who come in.
Mrs. Kincaid said the clinic is open to the public.

docBody.p: About a hundred attended the meeting, which began with a supper. Previous supper meetings have been held on the subjects of segregation and divorce.
